metadata.case_name: Appellant (son of Janki Pershad) v. State

facts.text: Appellant is an Under Secretary under suspension in the Ministry of Home Affairs, Government of India, New Delhi, and son of Janki Pershad.

Janki Pershad held a ration depot in Delhi. In 1948, he purchased three Post Office National Savings Certificates of face value Rs. 250/- in the name of Controller of Rationing, Delhi, and deposited them as security.
On February 21, 1952, Janki Pershad transferred the ration depot to his grandson S.K. Bansal, son of appellant.
On April 16, 1952, Janki Pershad applied to rationing authority for release of security, stating transfer to grandson who gave fresh cash security.
Janki Pershad died on June 1, 1952, before security was released.
On July 1, 1952, rationing authority wrote to Janki Pershad (unaware of death) that security released, sent form for transfer, certificates returned.
Appellant filled form for transfer, affixed signature purporting to be father's, attested it, affixed Ministry stamp, presented form and certificates at Post Office.
Post Office clerk doubted signature genuineness, but on appellant's assurance, issued fresh certificates in name of Janki Pershad on July 12, 1952.
On September 3, 1952, appellant signed three certificates on back as Janki Pershad for cancellation, attested with own signature and office stamp.
Appellant gave letter of authority purporting from Janki Pershad to Bhawani Shankar (daftri in his office) for cashing certificates.
Bhawani Shankar presented certificates, received Rs. 275/-, amount paid to appellant.
Appellant denied forging signatures, going to Post Office, deputing Bhawani Shankar, attesting signatures, affixing stamp; total denial.
Charges framed by Magistrate on September 8, 1956, under s.467 IPC, committed to Sessions.
Additional Sessions Judge, Delhi, on February 2, 1959, convicted under s.467 IPC, sentenced to imprisonment till rising of Court and fine Rs.250/-.
High Court (Punjab, Circuit Bench Delhi) dismissed appeal on January 7, 1960.
Concurrent findings: appellant forged signatures of father on application, certificates, letter of authority; attested them; got securities transferred and money received.

legal_issues.text: Whether appellant's actions in forging and attesting father's signatures on documents to transfer and encash certificates constitute forgery under s.467 IPC, despite being sole heir entitled to money.

petitioner_arguments.text: On findings, not guilty of forgery under s.464 IPC as received money due as sole heir; no gain to himself or injury to another.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.464 IPC; Dr. Vimla v. Delhi Administration

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant intended economic advantage by avoiding trouble/expense of succession certificate; forged to short-circuit procedures.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant made false documents dishonestly/fraudulently to cause wrongful gain (saving expense of succession certificate, avoiding delay/trouble of proving heirship to authorities).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Secured economic advantage by device; relieved of satisfying rationing/postal authorities of heirship, avoiding risk of refusal.

court_reasoning.text: Two procedures for heir: (1) succession certificate then release/encash; (2) after 3 months, prove sole heir to Post Master General if <Rs.5000. Appellant short-circuited both.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Should have informed rationing authority of death, obtained their application for transfer; likely needed succession certificate.

court_reasoning.text: Dr. Vimla case distinguished: there no economic/non-economic advantage to deceiver or loss to deceived; here appellant gained by saving expense/trouble.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 'Defraud' involves deceit + injury (non-economic too); benefit to deceiver causes loss to deceived.

holdings.text: Appellant guilty of forgery under s.463/464/467 IPC as made false documents dishonestly/fraudulently with intent to cause wrongful gain.

precedents_cited.relevance: No deceit + injury where no gain/loss; unlike here where economic/non-economic advantage secured.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines forgery, false document, dishonest/fraudulent intent; appellant's acts fit, causing wrongful gain.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; conviction and sentence under s.467 IPC by Additional Sessions Judge and High Court confirmed; concurrent findings of fact accepted.

key_quotes.text: A person is said to do a thing fraudulently if he does that thing with intent to defraud but not otherwise.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines fraudulent intent under s.25 IPC applied to facts.

key_quotes.text: The expression 'defraud' involves two elements, namely, deceit and injury to the person deceived. Injury is something other than economic loss...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Dr. Vimla, explains why distinguished: here injury/advantage present.

key_quotes.text: By adopting the aforesaid device he secured for himself a gain as otherwise he would have had to incur some expense for obtaining a succession certificate.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Crux of finding dishonest/fraudulent intent and wrongful gain.
